63049MRLCL6060H	1312210252096	007440473	CHROMIUM	TRI	2012	ENGINEERED COIL CO DBA DRS MARLO COIL	6060 HWY PP	HIGH RIDGE	JEFFERSON	MO	63049			YES	NO	NO	NO								333415						38.455417	-90.549389	071970180								MECCANICA HOLDINGS USA INC	828669007	SRNA:Source reduction of this chemical is not practical for this facility.  The amount of this chemical released, disposed and recycled on-site and/or off-site is directly tied to the facility's production.  This chemical is present in the materials (steel, stainless steel, etc.) used to make final products in amounts varying from 0% to 19%.  All scrap metals containing this chemical are recycled.  A quantity of this chemical is assumed to be present in the solid waste ( in 20 cubic yard roll-offs) that is disposed of annually.  Additionally, it is assumed that this chemical is deposited in trace amounts on-site each year.  Chromium fumes are also generated from welding activities which are reported as point source emissions. 46580MDCST596EA	1312210543258	007440473	CHROMIUM	TRI	2012	TEXMO PRECISION CASTINGS	596 E 200 N	WARSAW	KOSCIUSKO	IN	46582			YES	NO	NO	NO								331512						41.238033	-85.853073	144670056										In general practice,when we melt in open air induction furnace,the charge(metal ) is exposed to air which consists of 20.9% Oxygen. This Oxygen at high temperature reacts with the charge to form Oxides of Crome,Cobalt etc in the form of slag. It also creates Oxide effluent gas which goes in the air. SPAL process uses liquid Argon which being heavier forms a blanket over the molten metal in the furnace.Liquid Argon epands 800 times and it pushes the air(Oxygen) out of the furnace. We have implemented SPAL ( Surface Protection Air Liquide) in our melting practice,the Oxygen level over the molten bath is reduced from 20.9% to 2 %.This also reduces the slag by 75% and also reduces considerably the oxide effluent gas.	NO	CYNTHIA.RIEMERSMA@TEXMOCASTINGS.COM			YES

16603SMLLTSPRIN	1312210193557	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2012	ST PRODUCTS LLC (DBA SMALL TUBE PRODUCTS)	200 OLIPHANT DRIVE	DUNCANSVILLE	BLAIR	PA	16635			YES	NO	NO	NO								331421	331316					40.43647	-78.42152	118294891								QSTP HOLDCO LLC		STODDARD SOLVENT RECYCLING BY DISTILLATION VERSUS OFF-SITE DISPOSAL  In 2012, STP investigated the possibility of managing spent stoddard solvent as a Hazardous Secondary Material.  STP worked with Safety-Kleen Systems to determine the feasibility of this option.  This option is not feasible at this time because the recycled solvent that would be returned to STP could contain additional solvents other than stoddard solvent in concentrations less than 1%.   The additional solvents could affect Employee health and product quality.   In August of 2012, STP purchased a distillation machine to reclaim the stoddard solvent for reuse on site.  The distillation machine was in full production beginning in October 2012.  Preliminary data indicates that we are disposing of less spent stoddard solvent off-site as hazardous waste.  Some spent stoddard solvent cannot be recycled due to high amounts of suspended solids, oil and grease.  STP will continue to dispose of stoddard solvent that cannot be recycled (due to large amounts of impurities) and the waste still bottoms from the distillation machine as hazardous waste.    STP will continue to improve the efficiency of the distillation process in 2013.     STRAIGHT LENGTH TUBE DRAWING (OD, ID REDUCTION) Â¿ CHANGE FROM ANIMAL FAT BASED LUBRICANT TO PETROLEUM BASED LUBRICANT.  In 2012, continued experiments to determine if quality straight length tubing can be drawn using petroleum based lubricants versus an animal fat based lubricant.  The animal fat based lubricant is not recycled or burned for energy recovery; it is treated and disposed of as residual waste.  STP currently uses petroleum based lubricants to draw tubing in coil form.  These spent petroleum based lubricants are shipped off-site to waste oil disposal locations to be recycled or burned for energy recovery. Eliminating animal fat based lubricants would allow STP to ship nearly all lubricants off site to be recycled or burned for energy recovery.  This project will continue to be investigated in 2013.	NO	NOLIPHANT@SMALLTUBEPRODUCTS.COM			YES

Typically, the largest scrap from the process is in the beginning of a draw and the end of a draw. This joining of two bars end to end increased the time of the run reduced scrap significantly. Reductions are not quite linear as there is some loss for distortion at the bond line.  Furthermore, INCOM has been able to purchase 1.5 meter lengths versus the traditional one meter length. These will also allow for longer draws and less scrap.	NO	MAD@INCOMUSA.COM			YES

14094GNRLM200UP	1312210173201	007440508	COPPER	TRI	2012	GM COMPONENTS HOLDINGS LLC	200 UPPER MOUNTAIN RD MANUFACTURING PLANT	LOCKPORT	NIAGARA	NY	14094			YES	NO	NO	NO								336391	336399					43.165966	-78.740509	012839643	788733884							GENERAL MOTORS LLC	831247536	During 2012, GMCH Lockport became the 103rd General Motors Company facility to achieve landfill-free status by reusing, recycling or converting to energy all waste from its daily operations.  However, since some waste from daily operations went to landfill in the earlier part of 2012, TRI reports for the 2012 Reporting Year may show some constituents disposed to landfill. In addition, event waste (from one-time events, not associated with the daily, productive operations of the facility) may still be disposed via landfill if this is the only technical or economically feasible option.  Such event waste may be reportable on the TRI report, but does not negate the landfill-free status of the facility, as that status is from daily operations.  Waste from construction & demolition projects and environmental remediation are examples of event waste.   For more information on GMs Landfill-Free initiative, see "The Business Case for Zero Waste" (http://media.gm.com/content/dam/Media/documents/US/Word/101912-Landfill-free-blueprint.docx).  This downloadable blueprint is intended to help companies of all sizes and industries reduce waste and create efficiencies. 70734VNWTR34200	1312210107999	001330207	XYLENE (MIXED ISOMERS)	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC GEISMAR	34200 DISTRIBUTION LN	GEISMAR	ASCENSION PARISH	LA	70734			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						30.1832	-90.99716	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	DANIEL.WRIGHT@UNIVARUSA.COM			NO

60436PLLCL1550M	1312210498135	N040	BARIUM COMPOUNDS	TRI	2012	APOLLO COLORS INC	1550 MOUND RD	ROCKDALE	WILL	IL	60436			YES	NO	NO	NO								325132						41.500651	-88.122259	047578331								APOLLO COLORS INC	047578331	Part II.  Chemical-Specific Information (Barium Compounds) Apollo Colors Inc. uses Barium Chloride for specific Chemical Process Reactions.  The excess/residual Barium salts in all wastewater from reactions are pretreated to Barium Sulfate.  The Barium Sulfate is removed (filtered) from the the wastewater.  The Barium Sulfate (Filtrate) is sent to a Non-Hazardous Landfill.  The filtered wastewater is sent to the local POTW. With the delisting of Barium Sulfate as a reportable Hazardous Substance in 1995 by the U. S. EPA,  Apollo Colors Inc.  has eliminated reporting in Section 6.2  TRANSFERS TO OTHER OFF-SITE LOCATIONS.However,  Apollo Colors Inc. continues to report in Section 6.1 DISCHARGES TO PUBLICLY OWNED TREATMENT WORKS (POTW) because the local POTW does not differentiate between different kinds of Barium in the wastewater - POTW  permits are based on Total Barium.|SRNA:Although production increased in 2012 the amount of barium sulfate sent to the landfill decreased. 01432XNTCS115JA	1312210042750	N420	LEAD COMPOUNDS	PBT	2012	ADAPTIVE OPTICS ASSOCIATES	115 JACKSON RD	DEVENS	WORCESTER	MA	014344408			YES	NO	NO	NO								333314						42.541121	-71.619677	053634593								NORTHROP GRUMMAN CORP	016435559	We utilize a continuous improvement program team to recommend and evaluate pollution prevention methods. We have and will continue to monitor industry trends for lead alternatives for our product that will meet the performance requirements of our customers.  Currently there are no alternatives that produce acceptable performance. We continue to look at reuse of off- specification material in alternative lower grade products but have yet to identify a marketable solution.  Some of our lead based waste contains a precious metal and we have segregated this material and developed a relationship with a certified recycler who reclaims the precious metal and concentrates the lead waste stream thereby reducing hazardous waste from our manufacturing process.  We have evaluated process equipment improvements that would decrease lead based byproduct generation but the effort was unsuccessful in meeting the product specifications.  We have implemented "just-in-time" manufacturing techniques so that lead based material does not exceed its shelf-life and need to be discarded as hazardous waste.|SRNA:Lead is a key ingredient of our product and does not have an alternative available that will result in marketable performance. However, since some waste from daily operations went to landfill in the earlier part of 2012, TRI reports for the 2012 Reporting Year may show some constituents disposed to landfill. In addition, event waste (from one-time events, not associated with the daily, productive operations of the facility) may still be disposed via landfill if this is the only technical or economically feasible option.  Such event waste may be reportable on the TRI report, but does not negate the landfill-free status of the facility, as that status is from daily operations.  Waste from construction & demolition projects and environmental remediation are examples of event waste.   For more information on GMs Landfill-Free initiative, see "The Business Case for Zero Waste" (http://media.gm.com/content/dam/Media/documents/US/Word/101912-Landfill-free-blueprint.docx).  This downloadable blueprint is intended to help companies of all sizes and industries reduce waste and create efficiencies. Insufficient capital.The facility uses ammonia in the carburizing process used to increase the hardness of axle gears.  The ammonia disassociates at 850 degrees whereas the furnace temperature is 1550 degrees.  The facility made a conservative estimate in the Air Discharge permit of a 95% destruction rate.  This percentage was used to estimate the amount of ammonia that was released; in reality the actual destruction efficiency is probably in the 99-100% range.  There would be a very large cost to install an after-burner to destruct such a small amount of ammonia.   Additionally the facility did not have the capital to perform stack testing to determine the exact destruction level that is achieved in the furnaces themselves.	NO	THOMAS.COLLINS@ZF.COM			NO

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210430993	000107211	ETHYLENE GLYCOL	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes. 55965PRCRN701IN	1312210029841	000075070	ACETALDEHYDE	TRI	2012	PRO-CORN LLC (DBA POET PRESTON BIOREFINING)	701 IND US TRIAL DR N	PRESTON	FILLMORE	MN	55965			YES	NO	NO	NO								325193						43.6861	-92.0917	797683513								SOUTHEAST MINNESOTA ETHANOL LLC	797683513	SRNA:Acetaldehyde is produced during the fermentation process of creating ethanol.  The corn slurry is held in a temperature controlled tank (fermenter) for about 3 days.  While the corn slurry is transferred into the fermenter an enzyme is added to convert the corn starch to sugars.  During this time propagated dry batch yeast cells are added to the fermenter.  The hydrated yeast cells consume the sugars producing equal quantities of ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide gas.  Acetaldehyde is a byproduct of fermentation.  The acetaldehyde becomes entrained in the gas stream leaving the fermenter.  This gas stream is channeled through a wet scrubber before being burned in a Regenerative Thermal Oxidizer (RTO) or liquefied in a carbon dioxide purification plant.  The water flow rate on the wet scrubber is controlled to maintain compliance with environmental regulations based on emissions stack testing data.	NO	CHRIS.HANSON@POET.COM			NO	 	
55965PRCRN701IN	1312210029928	000064186	FORMIC ACID	TRI	2012	PRO-CORN LLC (DBA POET PRESTON BIOREFINING)	701 IND US TRIAL DR N	PRESTON	FILLMORE	MN	55965			YES	NO	NO	NO								325193						43.6861	-92.0917	797683513								SOUTHEAST MINNESOTA ETHANOL LLC	797683513	SRNA:Formic acid is produced during the fermentation process of creating ethanol.  The corn slurry is held in a temperature controlled tank (fermenter) for about 3 days.  While the corn slurry is transferred into the fermenter an enzyme is added to convert the corn starch to sugars.  During this time propagated dry batch yeast cells are added to the fermenter.  The hydrated yeast cells consume the sugars producing equal quantities of ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide gas.  Formic acid is a byproduct of fermentation.  Some of the formic acid becomes entrained in the gas stream leaving the fermenter.  This gas stream is channeled through a wet scrubber before being burned in a Regenerative Thermal Oxidizer (RTO) or liquefied in a carbon dioxide purification plant.  The water flow rate on the wet scrubber is controlled to maintain compliance with environmental regulations based on emissions stack testing data.  The remainder of the formic acid stays with the fermentation solids until they are dried in the dryers; the dryer gases are burned in an RTO.	NO	CHRIS.HANSON@POET.COM			NO

79762VNWTR311LA	1312210407781	000064186	FORMIC ACID	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC HOUSTON	7777 BRISBANE ST	HOUSTON	HARRIS	TX	77061			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						29.63819	-95.3006	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GREGORY.HEARD@UNIVAR.COM			NO

90502STWRT1161W	1312210825624	000108883	TOLUENE	TRI	2012	STEWART FILMSCREEN CORP	1161 W SEPULVEDA BLVD	TORRANCE	LOS ANGELES	CA	90502			YES	NO	NO	NO								326113						33.81243	-118.2961	008243885										Toluene and xylene are used as solvents in a mixture that polymerizes to form vinyl film screens, which are manufactured in dedicated spraying rooms with 100-percent capture of exhaust air. Neither the toluene nor the xylene is consumed in the process. The spray room exhaust contains organic vapors and particulate matter. Most of the toluene and xylene leave the spray room as vapor, but a miniscule amount adsorbs onto the surface of the dust particles. The exhaust enters two baghouses. The baghouses filter out most of the particulate matter, which is collected in drums. A small amount of toluene and xylene remain adsorbed onto the collected "baghouse dust" This toluene and xylene (less than 1 pound per year) goes along with the baghouse dust to an off-site disposal facility. The rest of the toluene and xylene leave the baghouses as (mainly) vapor and as adsorbate on the very fine particles that pass through the baghouse filters. The toluene and xylene vapors and the very fine toluene- and xylene-bearing particles enter a regenerative thermal oxidizer, which converts the toluene and xylene to carbon dioxide and water. A tiny fraction (0.80 percent) of the toluene and xylene is not oxidized and is released as a point source emission to the atmosphere.	NO	MARKR@STEWARTFILMSCREEN.COM			NO

This program endeavors to use the talents of our batch compounders and chemical formulators to develop new, more appropriate recipes for batches in an effort to successfully complete the batch without further processing.  Increasing the ¿first time right¿ percentage reduces waste, energy use, and reduces the use of other resources.  Over the last 4 years the Dap Tip City facility has increased the number of batches that have been successfully completed as first time right (FTR) . The manganese levels in the castings are determined by ASTM standards and is dependent upon the product mix and volume. Therefore the manganese levels in the castings cannot be intentionally reduced. It is Minncast's policy to reuse as much manganese as possible thereby minimizing the amount of manganese transferred off-site. As a member of the Metalcasters of Minnesota, it is Minncast's policy to stay current on the technology within the industry. Minncast will continue to evaluate different processes and equipment, both technically and economically, as part of its material monitoring program in an effort to reduce manganese releases from its facility. 98315NVLSBC8521	1312210445831	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2012	NAVAL BASE KITSAP BANGOR - RANGE ACTIVITIES	1101 TAUTOG CIRCLE	SILVERDALE	KITSAP	WA	983151087			NO	YES	YES	NO								928110						47.716667	-122.725			WA5170027291						US DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE		This form is being submitted for Range Activities at NBK Bangor.  The NBK Bangor facility contains two ranges that contribute to the lead contained in this report, a small arms range and a small Explosive Ordnance Disposal Open Burn/Open Detonation (OB/OD) site that is used for training and emergency disposal of munitions items that cannot be rendered inert and disposed of via traditional waste disposal methods.The Navy already employs an active pollution prevention program for the ranges designed to minimize releases at the sites.  The small arms range is indoors and enclosed and contains bullet traps to capture all spent bullets.  Addtionally, the ventilation for the building is routed through high effiiency dust collectors prior to exhausting to the outside air.  The OB/OD site employs a specially designed burn pan to minimize land releases of material to the environment as a result of OB/OD operations.  The Navy employs an active pollution prevention program with a dedicated staff member whose responsibility is to seek out and implement hazardous material and waste reduction efforts for NBK Bangor facility operations.  This program is implemented from the shop as well as management level and has been very successful in assisting with material and waste reduction efforts.  Significant recent pollution prevention activities include expansion of the Navy's Consolidated Hazardous Material Reutilization and Management Program (CHRIMP) to include more tenant activities as well as considerable research in the area of hazardous solvent usage reduction.|SRNA:This form is being submitted for Range Activities at NBK Bangor.  The NBK Bangor facility contains two ranges that contribute to the lead contained in this report, a small arms range and a small Explosive Ordnance Disposal Open Burn/Open Detonation (OB/OD) site that is used for training and emergency disposal of munitions items that cannot be rendered inert and disposed of via traditional waste disposal methods.The Navy already employs an active pollution prevention program for the ranges designed to minimize releases at the sites.  The small arms range is indoors and enclosed and contains bullet traps to capture all spent bullets.  Addtionally, the ventilation for the building is routed through high effiiency dust collectors prior to exhausting to the outside air.  The OB/OD site employs a specially designed burn pan to minimize land releases of material to the environment as a result of OB/OD operations.These two facilities are critical to the Navy's national security mission and must continue to be utilized at present utilization rates.  However, the design of the facilities ensures that releases of lead from range activities at the NBK Bangor facility are minimized.	YES	SILVIA.KLATMAN@NAVY.MIL			YES

73179VNWTR3320S	1312210105502	000111422	DIETHANOLAMINE	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC OKLAHOMA CITY	3320 S COUNCIL RD	OKLAHOMA CITY	OKLAHOMA	OK	73179			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.431986	-97.653602	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

55906RCHST425WS	1312210337655	N420	LEAD COMPOUNDS	PBT	2012	ROCHESTER PUBLIC UTILITIES SILVER LAKE PLANT	425 W SILVER LAKE DR NE	ROCHESTER	OLMSTED	MN	55906			YES	NO	NO	NO								221112						44.02765	-92.45997	012278354								ROCHESTER PUBLIC UTILITIES		RPU completed an Emissions Reduction Project (ERP) on Unit 4 in 2008/2009. The ERP utilizes a fabric filter baghouse and scrubber system for the reduction of acid gasses such as S02 and NOx, metals, such as lead and mercury and particulates.  The ERP also included an over-fire air which increases the combustion efficiency of Unit 4 and reduces the emission of NOx. The high pressure feed water heater on Unit 4 was also re-tubed which results in an improved heat rate (mmBtu/kw) of the boiler operation to reduce the amount of coal burned. This enables Silver Lake Power Plant to meet the electricity energy output schedule more efficiently. The system has been operational since 2009.	NO	TBENSON@RPU.ORG			YES

3950WCHNNL14373	1312210784462	000098862	ACETOPHENONE	TRI	2012	CHANNEL CHEMICAL CORP	14373 SEAWAY RD	GULFPORT	HARRISON	MS	39503			YES	NO	NO	NO								325199						30.43429	-89.08086	122687064										Acetophenone is a raw material that comes into the plant in metal 55 gal drums. Channel is adding a second warehouse for safe storage of the acetophenone drums. In addition Channel has implemented use of a special drum lift tool that attaches to the forklift to reduce the potential for spills when moving these drums from pallets into a water bath for heating. Acetophenone is shipped to the plant in metal drums by tractor trailer and stored in a future warehouse area.  Potential losses could occur during charging of the chemical to reactors (from drums), either from vapors as the drums are opened, or from drips that may occur during connection and disconnection of pumps and hoses. Both types of losses are very minimal. Occasional heavy rainwater flow will pick up residue from process areas, but it is contained within protective dikes.  Acetophenone is present in a process water that is sent offsite to a waste disposal company. In addition, empty acetophenone drums that contain a small amount of residue are stored until they are picked up by a drum recycling company and taken offsite.|W32:Channel Chemical bought a drum-lifting attachment for the forklift that allows an operator to safely lift drums of acetophenone into and out of the hot water bath. 16603SMLLTSPRIN	1312210193569	007440020	NICKEL	TRI	2012	ST PRODUCTS LLC (DBA SMALL TUBE PRODUCTS)	200 OLIPHANT DRIVE	DUNCANSVILLE	BLAIR	PA	16635			YES	NO	NO	NO								331421	331316					40.43647	-78.42152	118294891								QSTP HOLDCO LLC		STODDARD SOLVENT RECYCLING BY DISTILLATION VERSUS OFF-SITE DISPOSAL  In 2012, STP investigated the possibility of managing spent stoddard solvent as a Hazardous Secondary Material.  STP worked with Safety-Kleen Systems to determine the feasibility of this option.  This option is not feasible at this time because the recycled solvent that would be returned to STP could contain additional solvents other than stoddard solvent in concentrations less than 1%.   The additional solvents could affect Employee health and product quality.   In August of 2012, STP purchased a distillation machine to reclaim the stoddard solvent for reuse on site.  The distillation machine was in full production beginning in October 2012.  Preliminary data indicates that we are disposing of less spent stoddard solvent off-site as hazardous waste.  Some spent stoddard solvent cannot be recycled due to high amounts of suspended solids, oil and grease.  STP will continue to dispose of stoddard solvent that cannot be recycled (due to large amounts of impurities) and the waste still bottoms from the distillation machine as hazardous waste.    STP will continue to improve the efficiency of the distillation process in 2013.     STRAIGHT LENGTH TUBE DRAWING (OD, ID REDUCTION) ¿ CHANGE FROM ANIMAL FAT BASED LUBRICANT TO PETROLEUM BASED LUBRICANT.  In 2012, continued experiments to determine if quality straight length tubing can be drawn using petroleum based lubricants versus an animal fat based lubricant.  The animal fat based lubricant is not recycled or burned for energy recovery; it is treated and disposed of as residual waste.  STP currently uses petroleum based lubricants to draw tubing in coil form.  These spent petroleum based lubricants are shipped off-site to waste oil disposal locations to be recycled or burned for energy recovery. Eliminating animal fat based lubricants would allow STP to ship nearly all lubricants off site to be recycled or burned for energy recovery.  This project will continue to be investigated in 2013.	NO	NOLIPHANT@SMALLTUBEPRODUCTS.COM			YES

03301WKSDR330NO	1312211826502	007697372	NITRIC ACID	TRI	2012	HP HOOD LLC	330 N STATE ST	CONCORD	MERRIMACK	NH	03301			YES	NO	NO	NO								311511						43.233131	-71.561581	001008697								HP HOOD LLC	001008697	Nitric acid is the active ingredient in AC-55-5 Red and Passivation Acid, which are sanitizing agents used in the clean in place (CIP) processes at the HP Hood Concord Plant. According to the MSDS supplied by Ecolab, Inc., AC-55-5 Red contains 38% nitric acid by weight and Passivation Acid contains 23% nitric acid by weight. These chemicals are used to clean process tanks and vessels then discharged to a 21,352-gallon onsite wastewater equalization tank. The wastewater is pH neutralized in the tank through active chemical addition and then batch discharged to the Concord Wastewater Treatment Facility three to four times each production day. Use of the sanitizing agents and neutralization in the wastewater equalization tank dissociates the nitric acid into nitrate compounds and it is assumed that all of the nitric acid is treated onsite. However, there is a possibility that trace amounts of nitric acid are discharged to the POTW for treatment. Based on the quantities of nitric acid used, we calculate that HP Hood produced approximately 15,150 lbs of NaNO3 onsite during calendar year 2013, which is below the 25,000 lb threshold for manufacture. HP Hood is actively working with Ecolab to purchase sanitizing chemicals with lower concentrations of toxic chemicals.	NO	MICHAEL.ANDERSON@HPHOOD.COM			NO

A caustic scrubber is used to neutralize tank emissions. Potential losses could occur during charging of the chemical to totes (from the storage tank), to reactors (from totes), either from vapors as the totes are opened, or from drips that may occur during connection and disconnection of pumps and hoses. Prime western zinc comes to RMC with approximately 0.7% lead as an impurity.  The lead improves the flowing properties of the zinc resulting in an excellent zinc coating.  RMC has in the past attempted to use high grade zinc with a much lower percetage of lead instead of the prime western zinc.  The quality of the product suffered and, consequently, RMC returned to the use of prime western zinc. 24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210430942	000107131	ACRYLONITRILE	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes.  Per contract with DTI's customers, DTI does not own the process technology and is limited in its ability to substitute chemicals or modify the process.	NO	PBACON@DANCHEM.COM			NO

3950WCHNNL14373	1312210784548	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	CHANNEL CHEMICAL CORP	14373 SEAWAY RD	GULFPORT	HARRISON	MS	39503			YES	NO	NO	NO								325199						30.43429	-89.08086	122687064										Methanol is shipped to the plant in tanker trailers and is unloaded into a bulk storage tank that is located within a diked tank farm with recovery sumps.  It is pumped from the storage tank to reactors through heavy-duty chemical hoses. A portable tote is also filled from the methanol tank to be used on a scaled as needed for precise charging.  Fugitive emissions may occur from the storage tank (which usually has a nitrogen blanket on the contents), from the portable tote, or from the pump and hoses used to transfer the methanol to reactors.  These emissions are usually minimal. Spill protection has improved since a new tank farm was added to the plant site along with a new storage tank for methanol. 14094GNRLM200UP	1312210173237	007439965	MANGANESE	TRI	2012	GM COMPONENTS HOLDINGS LLC	200 UPPER MOUNTAIN RD MANUFACTURING PLANT	LOCKPORT	NIAGARA	NY	14094			YES	NO	NO	NO								336391	336399					43.165966	-78.740509	012839643	788733884							GENERAL MOTORS LLC	831247536	During 2012, GMCH Lockport became the 103rd General Motors Company facility to achieve landfill-free status by reusing, recycling or converting to energy all waste from its daily operations.  However, since some waste from daily operations went to landfill in the earlier part of 2012, TRI reports for the 2012 Reporting Year may show some constituents disposed to landfill. In addition, event waste (from one-time events, not associated with the daily, productive operations of the facility) may still be disposed via landfill if this is the only technical or economically feasible option.  Such event waste may be reportable on the TRI report, but does not negate the landfill-free status of the facility, as that status is from daily operations.  Waste from construction & demolition projects and environmental remediation are examples of event waste.   For more information on GMs Landfill-Free initiative, see "The Business Case for Zero Waste" (http://media.gm.com/content/dam/Media/documents/US/Word/101912-Landfill-free-blueprint.docx).  This downloadable blueprint is intended to help companies of all sizes and industries reduce waste and create efficiencies. However, since some waste from daily operations went to landfill in the earlier part of 2012, TRI reports for the 2012 Reporting Year may show some constituents disposed to landfill. In addition, event waste (from one-time events, not associated with the daily, productive operations of the facility) may still be disposed via landfill if this is the only technical or economically feasible option.  Such event waste may be reportable on the TRI report, but does not negate the landfill-free status of the facility, as that status is from daily operations.  Waste from construction & demolition projects and environmental remediation are examples of event waste.   For more information on GMs Landfill-Free initiative, see "The Business Case for Zero Waste" (http://media.gm.com/content/dam/Media/documents/US/Word/101912-Landfill-free-blueprint.docx). 79007VNWTR601LO	1312209989829	000111422	DIETHANOLAMINE	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC BORGER	601 S LOCUST ST	BORGER	HUTCHINSON	TX	79007			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.65993	-101.38752									UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT).    The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes    managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and    waste received into storage:    1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing.    2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life.    3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life.    4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates.    5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals.    6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste.    7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging.    8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product.    9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42).    10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210431110	000108883	TOLUENE	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes.  Per contract with DTI's customers, DTI does not own the process technology and is limited in its ability to substitute chemicals or modify the process.	NO	PBACON@DANCHEM.COM			NO

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210430955	N010	ANTIMONY COMPOUNDS	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes. 14094GNRLM200UP	1312210173249	007440020	NICKEL	TRI	2012	GM COMPONENTS HOLDINGS LLC	200 UPPER MOUNTAIN RD MANUFACTURING PLANT	LOCKPORT	NIAGARA	NY	14094			YES	NO	NO	NO								336391	336399					43.165966	-78.740509	012839643	788733884							GENERAL MOTORS LLC	831247536	During 2012, GMCH Lockport became the 103rd General Motors Company facility to achieve landfill-free status by reusing, recycling or converting to energy all waste from its daily operations.  However, since some waste from daily operations went to landfill in the earlier part of 2012, TRI reports for the 2012 Reporting Year may show some constituents disposed to landfill. In addition, event waste (from one-time events, not associated with the daily, productive operations of the facility) may still be disposed via landfill if this is the only technical or economically feasible option.  Such event waste may be reportable on the TRI report, but does not negate the landfill-free status of the facility, as that status is from daily operations.  Waste from construction & demolition projects and environmental remediation are examples of event waste.   For more information on GMs Landfill-Free initiative, see "The Business Case for Zero Waste" (http://media.gm.com/content/dam/Media/documents/US/Word/101912-Landfill-free-blueprint.docx).  This downloadable blueprint is intended to help companies of all sizes and industries reduce waste and create efficiencies. For more information on GMs environmental commitment, visit its sustainability report (http://www.gmsustainability.com/) and environmental blog (http://www.gmbeyondnow.com/). 24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210431033	000071363	N-BUTYL ALCOHOL	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the siteÂ¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes.  Per contract with DTI's customers, DTI does not own the process technology and is limited in its ability to substitute chemicals or modify the process.	NO	PBACON@DANCHEM.COM			NO

7739WSCHFF145SM	1312210641205	007439965	MANGANESE	TRI	2012	SCHUFF STEEL GULF COAST	14500 SMITH RD	HUMBLE	HARRIS	TX	77396			YES	NO	NO	NO								332312						29.93344	-95.28761									SCHUFF STEEL		SRNA:The releases described in this filing are minor and have been minimized to the extent practicable.  Schuff Steel (Gulf Coast), Inc. is a structural steel fabricator. The Humble facility is obligated to file TRI reports because the carbon steel grades processed at this facility include approximately 1% Manganese plus or minus other reportable trace metal components. The releases from this facilityinclude the following: (1) Releases to air from welding operations, which are estimated using published EPA emission factors (AP-42) and material through-puts. (2) Minor releases to landfills due to small quantities of fine metal particles becoming unavoidably entrained in plant trash (mostlyfrom floor sweepings; larger scrap metal pieces are re-used rather than disposed of). Landfill releases are estimated using conservative mass balance assumptions. This facility's operations are limited to structural fabrication and the facility does not engage in any surface abrasion, surface coating, or surface cleaning processes that would be expected to generate additional TRI-reportable organic or inorganic substances.	NO	PEDRO.MACIEL@SCHUFF.COM			YES

02717PRFRR66BRA	1312210110348	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2012	PREFERRED CONCRETE CORP	66 BRALEY RD	EAST FREETOWN	BRISTOL	MA	02717			YES	NO	NO	NO								327320						41.75872	-70.968	555823124										Description: Introduced fly ash into the ready-mix formulation. Fly ash reduces the quantity of cement needed to produce a yard of concrete. Benefits: Use of fly ash reduces the quantity of cement needed to produce a given volume of ready-mix concrete mixture. This result in a smaller quantity of lead for a given volume of concrete only when fly ash lead concentrations are lower than those found in cement.Obstacles: Fly ash contains similar lead concentrations as cement. Therefore, fly ash use will not significantly reduce the lead concentration in the ready-mix product. Higher fly ash concentrations increase curing time affecting the product¿s value to customers. Fly ash sources are limited and variable. Market forces affect availability.2012 Update: In 2012 Preferred Concrete obtained permission by the Town of Freetown to transport fly ash within the limits of the Town, a practice that was previously prohibited by the Town. As a result, Preferred is considering for future application use of fly ash in its ready mix concrete formulations. Fly ash is a byproduct of coal combustion. Energy production from combustion of coal has diminished recently due to the cost, availability, and use of natural gas. This, coupled with the recent shortage of fly ash from power plant shut downs has reduced the availability and increased the cost of fly ash in Massachusetts. Preferred continues to investigate this option and will implement it if and when it makes good business sense.	NO	PREFERREDSUE@AOL.COM			YES

51250MWGRS42015	1312210104562	007440508	COPPER	TRI	2012	GROSCHOPP INC	420 15TH ST NE	SIOUX CENTER	SIOUX	IA	51250			YES	NO	NO	NO								335312						43.09327	-96.17233	037662897								GROSCHOPP INC		The on-site point air emissions of copper decreased significantly from last year.  This is as a result of calculating emissions differently.  Previsously, emissions were calculated using an emission factor for wire welding for the entire wire.  In fusing, only a small percentage of the wire used is melted, so the amount of wire was divided by 100 (assuming 1% of wire is actually fused, the rest is wrapped around the stator).  Thus, you will note a 99% decrease in reported emissions.	NO	RYANO@GROSCHOPP.COM			YES

38024CLNLR150SO	1312210644795	N420	LEAD COMPOUNDS	PBT	2012	HEXPOL COMPOUNDING COLONIAL RUBBER WORKS	150 S CONNELL AVE	DYERSBURG	DYER	TN	38024			YES	NO	NO	NO								326299						36.03124	-89.39478	003613858								HEXPOL COMPOUNDING LLC	623825895	Teams were used to assess processes within the facility to improve line efficiency and control of raw materials. 46580MDCST596EA	1312210543260	007440484	COBALT	TRI	2012	TEXMO PRECISION CASTINGS	596 E 200 N	WARSAW	KOSCIUSKO	IN	46582			YES	NO	NO	NO								331512						41.238033	-85.853073	144670056										In general practice,when we melt in open air induction furnace,the charge(metal ) is exposed to air which consists of 20.9% Oxygen. This Oxygen at high temperature reacts with the charge to form Oxides of Crome,Cobalt etc in the form of slag. It also creates Oxide effluent gas which goes in the air. SPAL process uses liquid Argon which being heavier forms a blanket over the molten metal in the furnace.Liquid Argon epands 800 times and it pushes the air(Oxygen) out of the furnace. We have implemented SPAL ( Surface Protection Air Liquide) in our melting practice,the Oxygen level over the molten bath is reduced from 20.9% to 2 %.This also reduces the slag by 75% and also reduces considerably the oxide effluent gas.	NO	CYNTHIA.RIEMERSMA@TEXMOCASTINGS.COM			YES

This program endeavors to use the talents of our batch compounders and chemical formulators to develop new, more appropriate recipes for batches in an effort to successfully complete the batch without further processing.  Increasing the ¿first time right¿ percentage reduces waste, energy use, and reduces the use of other resources.  Over the last 4 years the Dap Tip City facility has increased the number of batches that have been successfully completed as first time right (FTR) .  These percentages are:        CY09  76.67%     CY10  80.71%     CY11  82.02%     CY12  86.55% As you can see, we have raised the average number of FTR batches by 10%. 73179VNWTR3320S	1312210105538	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC OKLAHOMA CITY	3320 S COUNCIL RD	OKLAHOMA CITY	OKLAHOMA	OK	73179			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.431986	-97.653602	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

00624CLCTRRD337	1312210322475	007664417	AMMONIA	TRI	2012	ECOELECTRICA LP	RD 337 KM 3.7 FIRM DELIVERY	PENUELAS	PENUELAS	PR	00624			YES	NO	NO	NO								221112						17.979	-66.7556	125305289										The facility implemented during 2012 a formal project to reduce ammonia used to control NOx emissions generated by the combustion of natural gas for the production of electricity. Ammonia is injected in a selective catalytic reactor (SCR). Prior to the injection of ammonia, water vapor is injected to attain certain levels of NOx. After the maximum reduction of NOx is achieved through water vapor injection, ammonia is injected to reduce them to reach applicable regulatory levels. The formal project included: an analysis of ammonia injection throughout a base year; identification of periods for which ammonia injection could be controlled further, replacement of old ammonia injection control valves for new ones which improved the response time between load changes in the combustion turbines and the fine tuning of water vapor injection to increase to a maximum the NOx reduction occurring before ammonia injection.  An approximate reduction of 15% of ammonia usage was attained with the project implementation.|W58:The manufacturer of the combustion turbines for which ammonia is used to reduce NOx emissions to comply with applicable regulations, completed a fine tunning of water vapor injection  which is used to reduce NOx emissions prior to ammonia inject|T06:Throughout the project implementation, representatives from the operations and maintenance departments participated in support to the environmental department which was leading the effort.|T01:A formal assessment of ammonia usage was completed. The 2010 was used as based year to complete an analysis of ammonia usage in the SCR throughout the various load changes in the combustion turbines.|T04:The project team which included personnel from the operations and maintenance departments provided feedback and recommendations for process improvement opportunities that would result in the reduction of ammonia usage for the control of NOx.|W52:Ammonia injection occurs in the selective catalytic reactor to control NOx emissions. The ammonia injection control valves were replaced by new ones to improve response time during the combustion turbines load changes.|T01:Based in the analysis completed for ammonia usage in the operation of the combustion turbines, areas of opportunity were identified to implement process and equipment improvements.	NO	DAMARIS.NEGRON@ECOELECTRICA.COM			NO

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210431007	000108316	MALEIC ANHYDRIDE	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes. 5424WSPNCR22SPA	1312210330902	007647010	HYDROCHLORIC ACID (1995 AND AFTER "ACID AEROSOLS" ONLY)	TRI	2012	SPANCRETE INDUSTRIES INC	2331 SPANCRETE RD	VALDERS	MANITOWOC	WI	54245			YES	NO	NO	NO								327390						44.06951	-87.87191	208609296										All spraying of hydrochloric acid occurs outdoors at the Spacrete facility in a defined outdoor area.  The spraying of the HCl forms an aerosol mist, which is included under EPCRA section 313 for both threshold and release determinations; liquid forms of HCl are not included under EPCRA section 313.  The amount of aerosol mist manufactured and otherwise used exceed both the threshold criteria of 25k lbs and 10k lbs respectively.  The aerosol mist that does not evaporate adheres to the concrete product surface where it condenses and via gravity flows off the product onto the ground.  To eliminate confusion, we have included this liquid product in this Form R report, since it is generated from the aerosol product.  The liquid that flows onto the ground then filters through a minimum of 1-foot thick crushed lime bed that helps raise the pH from ~ 2.0 to a minimum of 6.0, resulting in an assumed efficiency of 100%.	NO	SBERTSCHINGER@SPANCRETE.COM			NO

55965PRCRN701IN	1312210029904	000050000	FORMALDEHYDE	TRI	2012	PRO-CORN LLC (DBA POET PRESTON BIOREFINING)	701 IND US TRIAL DR N	PRESTON	FILLMORE	MN	55965			YES	NO	NO	NO								325193						43.6861	-92.0917	797683513								SOUTHEAST MINNESOTA ETHANOL LLC	797683513	SRNA:Formaldehyde is produced during the fermentation process of creating ethanol.  The corn slurry is held in a temperature controlled tank (fermenter) for about 3 days.  While the corn slurry is transferred into the fermenter an enzyme is added to convert the corn starch to sugars.  During this time propagated dry batch yeast cells are added to the fermenter.  The hydrated yeast cells consume the sugars producing equal quantities of ethyl alcohol and carbon dioxide gas.  Formaldehyde is a byproduct of fermentation.  The formaldehyde becomes entrained in the gas stream leaving the fermenter.  This gas stream is channeled through a wet scrubber before being burned in a Regenerative Thermal Oxidizer (RTO) or liquefied in a carbon dioxide purification plant.  The water flow rate on the wet scrubber is controlled to maintain compliance with environmental regulations based on emissions stack testing data.Formaldehyde is produced in an intermediate reaction in the combustion of natural gas.  POET Preston has two steam boilers capable of firing natural gas, two dryers with one natural gas burner each, and an RTO with three natural gas burners.	NO	CHRIS.HANSON@POET.COM			NO

70520VNWTR220HE	1312210407817	000108883	TOLUENE	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC LAFAYETTE	220 HECTOR CONNOLY RD	CARENCRO	LAFAYETTE PARISH	LA	70520			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						30.32294	-92.02853	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT).    The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes    managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and    waste received into storage:    1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing.    2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life.    3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life.    4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates.    5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals.    6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste.    7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging.    8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product.    9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42).    10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	BRYCE.LYONS@UNIVARUSA.COM			NO

79762VNWTR311LA	1312210407490	N230	CERTAIN GLYCOL ETHERS	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC HOUSTON	7777 BRISBANE ST	HOUSTON	HARRIS	TX	77061			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						29.63819	-95.3006	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GREGORY.HEARD@UNIVAR.COM			NO

49508LLDFN4100B	1312210060404	N090	CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS(EXCEPT CHROMITE ORE MINED IN THE TRANSVAAL REGION)	TRI	2012	ALLIED FINISHING INC	4100 BROADMOOR SE	KENTWOOD	KENT	MI	49512			YES	NO	NO	NO								332813						42.88889	-85.56933	085890846								ALLIED FINISHING INC		We plate over hollow Aluminum tubes. Which got plated on outside surface. The surface that is inside the hollow tube remains non plated, Aluminum. As that parts progress through the process, the inner exposed Aluminum would dissolved in the plating baths. Which turned out to be an impurity . This proved detrimental to chromium plating baths. It took a while to identify the problem, in past we decanted chromium plating baths when Aluminum concentration got high.Over period of time, we have learn to assign only one chromium plating bath to Aluminum substrate we also have had to figure out the maximum concentration bath would allow without producing scarp . Now we decant only one bath, instead of 6 baths. We also have learnt process much better to understand level of Aluminum at which it becomes detrimental to plating process.We also started sending spent chrome solution to place that reuses it instead of treat and land fill.|W19:Prior to any part  being considered for plating, it goes through a critical team review of rack design ,  a very important factor, discussed is, the drainage of the solution while transferring parts from one tank to the next to avoid cross conta|T01:It is job description of certain individual to keep track of the health of the tanks to avoid any leakage and avoid spillage.Tanks they show weakness in strength are immediately repaierd or replaced depending on the need.|T04:Every week , twice a week 8 people from variety of department meet with the owner of comany to to discuss technical issues one important agenda is pollution prevention.|T05:Many individuals are involved to maintain quality of process and equipment, each participates freely to communicate and prevent future potential problematic sources and we work on those issue as a preventive measure,|W36:On going|T01:Solution maintenance and maintenance department have their routine checks in place.|T04:Technical team involvement is valued|T05:Each and all employees are encourage to participate.	NO	BRUCE.STONE@ALLIEDFINISHINGINC.COM			YES

79762VNWTR311LA	1312210407639	000107211	ETHYLENE GLYCOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC HOUSTON	7777 BRISBANE ST	HOUSTON	HARRIS	TX	77061			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						29.63819	-95.3006	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GREGORY.HEARD@UNIVAR.COM			NO

When the wooden baffles, impregnated with lead from the firing of rounds, need replacing, the weight totals for lead waste debris increase significantly due to the weight of the wood.|SRNA:Pollution prevention previously implemented - additional reduction does not appear technically or economically feasible. All of the lead waste and lead releases are generated at the Base Portsmouth outdoor small arms firing range. Pollution prevention procedures are closely followed to minimize the lead concentrations in the stormwater discharges and there is no way feasible to capture fugitive emmissions at an outdoor firing range. The only way to improve the pollution prevention capabilities would be to construct an indoor firing range which would eliminate lead being discharged into the stormwater discharges and it would also eliminate fugitive emmissions from the firing of rounds. Unfortunately, at this time, constructing an indoor firing range is not economically feasible.	YES	GENE.C.LEONARD@USCG.MIL			YES

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210430967	N100	COPPER COMPOUNDS	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the siteÂ¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes.  Per contract with DTI's customers, DTI does not own the process technology and is limited in its ability to substitute chemicals or modify the process.	NO	PBACON@DANCHEM.COM			YES
