24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210431021	000080626	METHYL METHACRYLATE	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes.  Per contract with DTI's customers, DTI does not own the process technology and is limited in its ability to substitute chemicals or modify the process.	NO	PBACON@DANCHEM.COM			NO

5464WCSTLRINTER	1312210592566	000075070	ACETALDEHYDE	TRI	2012	MARQUIS ENERGY-WISCONSIN LLC	N9585 STATE ROAD 80	NECEDAH	JUNEAU	WI	54646			YES	NO	NO	NO								325193						43.99187	-90.07219											Acetaldehyde is produced during fermentation, and off gases are sent to the CO2 scrubber for removal of acetaldehyde. Acetaldehyde within the scrubber liquid stream is recycled back to the cook water tank for use in fermentation.  During fermentation, the yeast used to convert the sugar to ethyl alcohol metabolizes the acetaldehyde. The packed bed scrubber is used to remove acetaldehyde emissions. Acetaldehyde emissions are also generated during wet feed drying. Emissions are reduced by the thermal oxidizer during wet feed drying, and the flare during ethanol loadout activities. 79762VNWTR311LB	1312210407437	000107211	ETHYLENE GLYCOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC ODESSA	311 LARK AVE	ODESSA	ECTOR	TX	79762			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						31.87214	-102.30488									UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

Thus, some years it may be appropriate for us to select the range of 11-499 lbs/yr, which gives us a total release value in the mid-200s. Other years it's appropriate for us to select the range of 1-10 lbs/yr., which gives us a total relase value between 8-15 lbs/yr. 7702WSCHFF492AI	1312210640153	007440473	CHROMIUM	TRI	2012	SCHUFF STEEL GULF COAST (AIRLINE)	4920 AIRLINE DR	HOUSTON	HARRIS	TX	77022			YES	NO	NO	NO								332312						29.83842	-95.38427									SCHUFF STEEL		SRNA:The Schuff Steel (Gulf Coast) Airline facility is a structural steel and stainless steel fabricator which generates minimal metal releases from processing activities. This facility is obligated to file TRI reports because the steel grades processed at this facility include chromium, manganese, and nickel.  In certain years depending on production levels, one or more of these metals may be processed in a quantity that exceeds TRI reporting thresholds. The releases from this facility include the following: (1) Minor releases to air from welding operations, which are estimated using published EPA emission factors (AP-42) and associated material through-puts. (2) Minor releases to landfills due to small quantities of fine metal particles becoming unavoidably entrained in plant trash (mostly from floor sweepings; larger scrap metal pieces are re-used rather than disposed of). Landfill releases are estimated using conservative mass balance assumptions. This facility's operations are limited to structural fabrication and the facility does not engage in any toxic chemical manufacture, surface abrasion, surface coating, or surface cleaning processes that would be expected to generate additional TRI-reportable organic or inorganic substances.	NO	PEDRO.MACIEL@SCHUFF.COM			YES

73179VNWTR3320S	1312210105526	000107211	ETHYLENE GLYCOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC OKLAHOMA CITY	3320 S COUNCIL RD	OKLAHOMA CITY	OKLAHOMA	OK	73179			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.431986	-97.653602	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

60007RCTRN1150P	1312210610681	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2012	ARC-TRONICS INC	1150 PAGNI DR	ELK GROVE VILLAGE	COOK	IL	60007			YES	NO	NO	NO								334418						42.02771	-87.96691	059428250										Lead-Free solders continue to increase in our industry. Out of our current customer base only 15% are requiring lead-free solders. We continue to see increase in customers designed product that will require lead-free solder. The additional lead-free requirements should have a direct effect on the leaded products we build, resulting in a reduction in use of leaded solders.|SRNA:Source reduction has been an ongoing process at our facility. Our manufacturing equipment and maintenance programs have all been setup to minimize the lead waste. All lead waste streams that are generated are send off site for recycling. Our industry has been and is continuing it's journey in replacing leaded solders with lead-free solders. Since we are custom assembly manufacture, and we do not design the products we build, we must rely on our customers to design out the use of leaded solders. Many of our customers are medical, defense and aerospace, which currently have exemptions in the use of lead-free solders. These exemptions will be expired in the 12 - 24 months, so we anticipate our customers redesigning their products, using lead-free solders. These redesigns will have a direct effect on our use of leaded solders, therefore we will see a reduction in the use of these materials.	NO	MATTHEWG@ARC-TRONICS.COM			YES

90064BRRYV2210B	1312210800696	007697372	NITRIC ACID	TRI	2012	BARRY AVENUE PLATING CO	2210 BARRY AVE	LOS ANGELES	LOS ANGELES	CA	90064			YES	NO	NO	NO								332813						34.03449	-118.44661	009688185										Barry Avenue Plating is continuously finding ways to reduce the generation of the hazardous wastes and usage of hazardous materials. In the last few years we have included in our process ROHS compliant chemistries such as the trivalent chrome plate, Trivalent chem films and non-hex chrome supplementary coatings. We have installed HEPA unit/Filters to reduce our emission in both Chromic Anodizing department and Paint department. Most of the generated hazardous wastes that were sent off-site for treatment were recycled, sent for further chemical treatment or energy recovery. This year we started  metal recycling of our metal scraps which include of copper wires, stainless steel wires, racks and other metals bearing parts. This year we are also starting the Re-Use Water project. This project involves recycling the wastewater generated during in processing. 48234WDWRT20251	1312210114486	007664417	AMMONIA	TRI	2012	COOPER HEAT TREATING LLC	20251 SHERWOOD	DETROIT	WAYNE	MI	48234			YES	NO	NO	NO								332811						42.445833	-83.035	078816552										SRNA:Anhydrous ammonia is the compound by the combination of two gaseous elements, nitrogen and hydrogen, in the proportion of one part nitrogen to three parts hydrogen by volume. Since one volume of nitrogen weighs fourteen times as much as one volume of hydrogen, on a weight basis, the ratio is fourteen parts of nitrogen to three parts of hydrogen, or about 82% nitrogen and 18% hydrogen. At atmospheric temperatures and pressures, anhydrous ammonia is a pungent colorless gas. Anhydrous ammonia boils at -28Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â°F (at 1atm) and freezes to a white crystalline mass at -108Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â°F. When heated above its critical temperature of 271.4Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â°F, ammonia exist as a vapor regardless of the pressure. Between the melting and critical points, liquid ammonia exerts a vapor pressure, which increases with rising temperature. When liquid ammonia is in a solid container, it is in equilibrium with ammonia vapor and the pressure within the container bears a definite relationship to the temperature. Above 900Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â¿Ã¿Â°F, ammonia begins to decompose, reverting to hydrogen and nitrogen. The process at Woodworth Inc., involves ammonia being introduced into the furnaces as a vapor. The nitrogen is diffused into the surface layer of the metal and the hydrogen is exhausted to the furnace burn-off stack, where it is mixed with natural gas and it is ignited by a pyrotechnic device to insure complete combustion. OtherLead is present in trace amounts in various chemicals and incoming raw materials.  We will evaluate reviewing these chemicals for scrutiny or replacement, but some chemicals are used based on quality or safety, which may not be easily replaced.  Another source of the trace lead is in the incoming recycled wastepaper the facility uses.  Since the sources of wastepaper is almost infinite, it is practically infeasible to control incoming lead which may not be present or which may only be present in ppm or ppb quantities. However, since SCA promotes sustainability and has an philosophy of continual environmental improvement, this concern will be evaluated when feasible.Since lead is present in trace amounts and the facility has not done routine testing in the past, then the lead may or may not show up in the effluent wastewater or in the sludge shipped to the landfill. 1471WCHTQP1287H	1312210906210	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2012	CHAUTAUQUA PRECISION MACHINING INC	1287 HUNT ROAD	ASHVILLE	CHAUTAUQUA	NY	14710			YES	NO	NO	NO								332721						42.08958	-79.35516	963994038										The parts we make from alloys containing lead are machined using oil as a coolant to move scrap metal turnings down to the bottom of the machine where the oil is recirculated.  Next we remove the scrap metal turnings and put them through a centrifuge which spins out the oil leaving dry turnings, then we process the oil through another centrafuge which separates out smaller particles of the turnings.  Clean oil is then reused in the machining process.  The turnings are then put into containers to go to a metal recycler.  Our estimates are based on recent professional testing of our oil, waste water, absorbent pads, grinding coolant, grinding cludge and grinding wheels.	NO	MATTARD@CHAUT-PREC.COM			YES

70520VNWTR220HE	1312210407680	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC LAFAYETTE	220 HECTOR CONNOLY RD	CARENCRO	LAFAYETTE PARISH	LA	70520			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						30.32294	-92.02853	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	BRYCE.LYONS@UNIVARUSA.COM			NO

The chromium levels in the castings are determined by ASTM standards and is dependent upon the product mix and volume. Therefore the chromium levels in the castings cannot be intentionally reduced. As a member of the Metalcasters of Minnesota, it is Minncast's policy to stay current on the technology within the industry. Minncast will continue to evaluate different processes and equipment, both technically and economically, as part of its material monitoring program in an effort to reduce chromium releases from its facility. 73179CHMCN7301S	1312210105401	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA OKLAHOMA CITY 29TH STREET	7301 SW 29TH ST	OKLAHOMA CITY	OKLAHOMA	OK	73179			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.43522	-97.64072	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	MICHAEL.BUTZ@UNIVARUSA.COM			NO

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210430930	000079107	ACRYLIC ACID	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes.  Per contract with DTI's customers, DTI does not own the process technology and is limited in its ability to substitute chemicals or modify the process.	NO	PBACON@DANCHEM.COM			NO

Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210431060	007697372	NITRIC ACID	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes. The amount of this chemical released, disposed and recycled on-site and/or off-site is directly tied to the facility's production.  This chemical is present in the materials (steel, stainless steel, etc.) used to make final products in amounts varying from 0% to 30%.  All scrap metals containing this chemical are recycled. When 200-proof ethyl alcohol is produced, transportation regulations require that the ethanol be unfit for human consumption.  The ethanol has natural gasoline added to create a 95-98% ethanol / 5-2% natural gasoline finished product.  The natural gasoline is manufactured with 9.61% hexane.  The releases of hexane are based on the emissions associated with handling and storing of the natural gasoline. Hexane is produced in an intermediate reaction in the combustion of natural gas. 24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210431185	001330207	XYLENE (MIXED ISOMERS)	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the siteÂ¿s discharge. 24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210431019	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the siteÂ¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes. 73179VNWTR3320S	1312210105553	000108883	TOLUENE	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC OKLAHOMA CITY	3320 S COUNCIL RD	OKLAHOMA CITY	OKLAHOMA	OK	73179			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.431986	-97.653602	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

It is highly regulated and the chloroform can only be used once.  This is a closed loop system with zero emissions to air and 100% of the chloroform used is transported off-site as hazardous waste for incineration. DePuy is researching options for a process that will permit a single re-use of the chloroform, which would halve the amount required at present production volumes.  There may be growth in this sector, so the goal is to minimize the use of chloroform while maximizing the production of this product. DePuy has a model from one of its sister companies that re-uses the chloroform once, and that system will be installed at this facility in 2014. 90502STWRT1161W	1312210825699	001330207	XYLENE (MIXED ISOMERS)	TRI	2012	STEWART FILMSCREEN CORP	1161 W SEPULVEDA BLVD	TORRANCE	LOS ANGELES	CA	90502			YES	NO	NO	NO								326113						33.81243	-118.2961	008243885										Toluene and xylene are used as solvents in a mixture that polymerizes to form vinyl film screens, which are manufactured in dedicated spraying rooms with 100-percent capture of exhaust air. Neither the toluene nor the xylene is consumed in the process. The spray room exhaust contains organic vapors and particulate matter. Most of the toluene and xylene leave the spray room as vapor, but a miniscule amount adsorbs onto the surface of the dust particles. The exhaust enters two baghouses. The baghouses filter out most of the particulate matter, which is collected in drums. A small amount of toluene and xylene remain adsorbed onto the collected "baghouse dust." This toluene and xylene (less than 1 pound per year) goes along with the baghouse dust to an off-site disposal facility. The rest of the toluene and xylene leave the baghouses as (mainly) vapor and as adsorbate on the very fine particles that pass through the baghouse filters. The toluene and xylene vapors and the very fine toluene- and xylene-bearing particles enter a regenerative thermal oxidizer, which converts the toluene and xylene to carbon dioxide and water. A tiny fraction (0.80 percent) of the toluene and xylene is not oxidized and is released as a point source emission to the atmosphere.	NO	MARKR@STEWARTFILMSCREEN.COM			NO

77041HSTNS11235	1312210407589	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC HOUSTON FM 529	11235 FM 529	HOUSTON	HARRIS	TX	77041			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						29.88023	-95.57905	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	WILLIE.GREEN@UNIVARUSA.COM			NO

73179VNWTR3320S	1312210105540	000108101	METHYL ISOBUTYL KETONE	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC OKLAHOMA CITY	3320 S COUNCIL RD	OKLAHOMA CITY	OKLAHOMA	OK	73179			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.431986	-97.653602	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customerÃ¿Â¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.|T11:Removed Bulk Methanol Storage tank from service.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

55906RCHST425WS	1312210337630	007647010	HYDROCHLORIC ACID (1995 AND AFTER "ACID AEROSOLS" ONLY)	TRI	2012	ROCHESTER PUBLIC UTILITIES SILVER LAKE PLANT	425 W SILVER LAKE DR NE	ROCHESTER	OLMSTED	MN	55906			YES	NO	NO	NO								221112						44.02765	-92.45997	012278354								ROCHESTER PUBLIC UTILITIES		RPU completed an Emissions Reduction Project (ERP) on Unit 4 in 2008/2009. The ERP utilizes a fabric filter baghouse and scrubber system for the reduction of acid gasses such as S02 and NOx, metals, such as lead and mercury and particulates.  The ERP also included an over-fire air which increases the combustion efficiency of Unit 4 and reduces the emission of NOx. The high pressure feed water heater on Unit 4 was also re-tubed which results in an improved heat rate (mmBtu/kw) of the boiler operation to reduce the amount of coal burned. This enables Silver Lake Power Plant to meet the electricity energy output schedule more efficiently. The system has been operational since 2009.	NO	TBENSON@RPU.ORG			NO

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210431159	000108054	VINYL ACETATE	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes.  Per contract with DTI's customers, DTI does not own the process technology and is limited in its ability to substitute chemicals or modify the process.	NO	PBACON@DANCHEM.COM			NO

70520VNWTR220HE	1312210407906	001330207	XYLENE (MIXED ISOMERS)	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC LAFAYETTE	220 HECTOR CONNOLY RD	CARENCRO	LAFAYETTE PARISH	LA	70520			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						30.32294	-92.02853	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	BRYCE.LYONS@UNIVARUSA.COM			NO

79007VNWTR601LO	1312209989882	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA INC BORGER	601 S LOCUST ST	BORGER	HUTCHINSON	TX	79007			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.65993	-101.38752									UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	GAIL.BACKUS@UNIVAR.COM			NO

24540DNRVRSTATE	1312210430979	000110827	CYCLOHEXANE	TRI	2012	DANCHEM TECHNOLOGIES INC	1975 OLD RICHMOND RD	DANVILLE	PITTSYLVANIA	VA	24540			YES	NO	NO	NO								325211	325520	325181	325411			36.60925	-79.3636	607417441								EDGEWATER CAPITAL PARTNERS LP	058291399	In the past, DanChem Technologies (DTI) has relied on underground piping as a means to get process wastewater from various locations throughout the chemical manufacturing areas to the site's effluent basin.  The basin was a lined surface impoundment designed to collect high pH wastewater from areas of the site and mix with low pH wastewater from other areas of the site in an attempt to neutralize prior to discharge to the City of Danville Wastewater Treatment Facility.  Operation of the system was regulated under an Industrial Wastewater Discharge Permit which required continuous monitoring for pH and periodic monitoring for concentrations of chemical contamination.   Although there were no regulatory mandates which forced the elimination of the effluent basin, in August 2011, DTI voluntarily began the construction of a new wastewater treatment facility to completely eliminate the effluent basin and start utilizing the latest technologies in wastewater treatment and pollution prevention.  In August 2012, one year following the start of the project, all wastewater from across the site was being pumped through an above ground piping system and was being accumulated in a series of storage tanks within the  secondary containment of the new wastewater tank farm.  By the end of 2012, the new wastewater treatment facility went operational and began treating the site¿s discharge.  DTI is currently exploring opportunities to reuse the discharge from the wastewater treatment facility.|SRNA:DanChem Technologies (DTI) is a custom or toll chemical manufacturer producing materials on behalf of other chemical manufacturers following their prescribed formulations and processes.  Per contract with DTI's customers, DTI does not own the process technology and is limited in its ability to substitute chemicals or modify the process.	NO	PBACON@DANCHEM.COM			NO

73179CHMCN7301S	1312210105464	000107197	PROPARGYL ALCOHOL	TRI	2012	UNIVAR USA OKLAHOMA CITY 29TH STREET	7301 SW 29TH ST	OKLAHOMA CITY	OKLAHOMA	OK	73179			YES	NO	NO	NO								424690						35.43522	-97.64072	102971785								UNIVAR USA INC	102971785	Univar USA Inc. is a Chemical Distributor.   Volumes of chemicals repackaged and transferred vary year to year based upon market demands.  Univar implements pollution prevention activities and is conscientious regarding impact to the environment.  Univar USA Inc. uses currently available methods of treatment and/or disposal for hazardous wastes, which minimizes the present and future threat to human health and the environment. These methods are in the treatment standards and technologies contained in the RCRA hazardous waste regulations, or are the best demonstrated available technologies (BDAT). The following Univar USA Inc. waste minimization program applies to all wastes managed at the facility, including wastes generated from operations on-site and waste received into storage: 1. Personnel have been trained in procedures to reduce the creation of waste resulting from poor operational practices, such as damage during warehousing. 2. A standard operating practice of rotating stock has been established to keep inventory from exceeding its recommended shelf life. 3. A standard operating practice has been established to maintain inventories at an appropriate level to only service our customer¿s needs, reducing the potential for product to exceed its recommended shelf life. 4. A standard operating practice has been established to identify excess product inventories and to sell products nearing their shelf-life dates. 5. A standard operating practice has been established which requires us to contact manufacturers of the products we warehouse to recycle out-of-date and damaged chemicals. 6. A standard operating practice of equipment dedication (as feasible) reduces the need to create line flush waste. 7. A standard operating practice has been established to reduce the amount of material used when flushing the lines before repackaging. 8. A standard operating practice has been established to develop customers that can beneficially use line flush as product. 9. A program for introducing new and innovative technology is in place to utilize equipment and develop operating practices which will reduce the amount of waste created (OSM 6.42). 10. A management team has been formed to develop methods of reducing waste generated.	NO	MICHAEL.BUTZ@UNIVARUSA.COM			NO

16603SMLLTSPRIN	1312210193544	007440508	COPPER	TRI	2012	ST PRODUCTS LLC (DBA SMALL TUBE PRODUCTS)	200 OLIPHANT DRIVE	DUNCANSVILLE	BLAIR	PA	16635			YES	NO	NO	NO								331421	331316					40.43647	-78.42152	118294891								QSTP HOLDCO LLC		STODDARD SOLVENT RECYCLING BY DISTILLATION VERSUS OFF-SITE DISPOSAL  In 2012, STP investigated the possibility of managing spent stoddard solvent as a Hazardous Secondary Material.  STP worked with Safety-Kleen Systems to determine the feasibility of this option.  This option is not feasible at this time because the recycled solvent that would be returned to STP could contain additional solvents other than stoddard solvent in concentrations less than 1%.   The additional solvents could affect Employee health and product quality.   In August of 2012, STP purchased a distillation machine to reclaim the stoddard solvent for reuse on site.  The distillation machine was in full production beginning in October 2012.  Preliminary data indicates that we are disposing of less spent stoddard solvent off-site as hazardous waste.  Some spent stoddard solvent cannot be recycled due to high amounts of suspended solids, oil and grease.  STP will continue to dispose of stoddard solvent that cannot be recycled (due to large amounts of impurities) and the waste still bottoms from the distillation machine as hazardous waste.    STP will continue to improve the efficiency of the distillation process in 2013.     STRAIGHT LENGTH TUBE DRAWING (OD, ID REDUCTION) Ã¿Â¿ CHANGE FROM ANIMAL FAT BASED LUBRICANT TO PETROLEUM BASED LUBRICANT.  In 2012, continued experiments to determine if quality straight length tubing can be drawn using petroleum based lubricants versus an animal fat based lubricant.  The animal fat based lubricant is not recycled or burned for energy recovery; it is treated and disposed of as residual waste.  STP currently uses petroleum based lubricants to draw tubing in coil form.  These spent petroleum based lubricants are shipped off-site to waste oil disposal locations to be recycled or burned for energy recovery. Eliminating animal fat based lubricants would allow STP to ship nearly all lubricants off site to be recycled or burned for energy recovery.  This project will continue to be investigated in 2013.	NO	NOLIPHANT@SMALLTUBEPRODUCTS.COM			YES
